singleTweet.author: @Forbes
singleTweet.text: Read more on the unlikely rise of Turkey’s e-commerce queen: https://t.co/T5JKvV9XRi

singleTweet.author: @Forbes
singleTweet.text: Today, her e-commerce companies are worth an estimated $2 billion, far greater than the media conglomerate built by her father, a former billionaire often described as the Rupert Murdoch of Turkey

singleTweet.author: @Forbes
singleTweet.text: That stubbornness stayed with her. After working at the family business, Dogan Holding, she decided to strike out on her own. For the daughter of one Turkey’s wealthiest magnates, that meant spending $10 million of inherited family funds to purchase digital assets

singleTweet.author: @Forbes
singleTweet.text: “My father used to sit at the head of the dinner table, and when Hanzade was young she made a big issue that she was going to sit at the head of the table,” Dogan-Boyner’s sister Vuslat recalls. “My father didn’t want to give his space to her, but she was stubborn about it.” https://t.co/1HBmq3Arbt

singleTweet.author: @Forbes
singleTweet.text: For years, Dogan-Boyner’s father owned and published one of Turkey’s premier newspaper franchises. As with the rest of her sisters, she was expected to attend Turkish schools and join the family business. But she had a strong will from a young age

singleTweet.author: @Forbes
singleTweet.text: Hanzade Dogan-Boyner is now one of the most successful women tech entrepreneurs in the world. But had she not defied her father and quit her family business, she would not have built what is being called Turkey’s Amazon https://t.co/cdxcJJ37jY https://t.co/x3hjGBqeQc
